description: Marisa Cornelius Anger.   You know those stages of grief? All I have is anger, mostly. At everything and everyone.   I've now lived a week and a day in this world without my grandmother in it. The matriarch of our family. It seems so strange to look out the window and see life continuing on the same as before. So many people going about their business as usual while my life has... been halted... shattered.. by reality. By time. By cancer.   Most people's earliest memories include their mother. My earliest memories of my mother are intertwined with memories of my grandmother. I know I've been extremely lucky to have had her in my life well into my thirties. My children have grown up with her being very much a part of their world as well. My heart aches for their loss.   I am sad. I am lonely. I am broken.   I am wanting to reach out without actually having to speak to anyone. I am not ready to "process." I am not apologizing for my anger or standoffishness. However, I do request:   remember that there is so much that goes on unseen in the lives of those around you. Even if they haven't "earned it," Be kind. Marisa Lynn D. McDonald

description: Marisa Cornelius It's not your birthday. It's not St Patty's. It's not the day you unexpectedly left us. It's a Saturday. It's Saturday and I miss you. I miss you a lot. I never had the privilege of meeting you in person, but you were one of my best friends,  Caitlin Titus ,  nonetheless. You were my musical soulmate, Marmoset. And fuck you for dying, by the way. I've had a ridiculous amount of loss in the last three years... A ridiculous amount. It's so fucking heavy I fear to stand. And I'm certain of two things. The first is that you'd give me perspective and make me feel even the smallest bit better. The second is that you'd indefinitely have an inappropriate joke on the subject for me. To which I'd respond with a sideways glare and guilty laugh. My friends, Marmoset, my friends are gone. My family, they are dead too. I miss them. And I miss you, my confidant. Rest well, my friend. The only response I expect of you is a giant middle finger in the sky. Maybe some Violeta. Say hi once in awhile, would ya? We miss you.   There'll be days like this.

My theory is that the squirrel maybe* infected with Toxoplasmosis. description: James Hasapis 9/28 UPDATE: STREET MURAL ASPEN/LE RUEX INTERSECTION  This morning I had a conference call with the CVB Leadership regarding the street mural. We had a great conversation. And let's first address the elephant in the room. The street mural is not going away. It is temporary and will be there for a number of months to a year.  Now that is out of the way. I shared with them that my post did not initiate the negative Facebook response, but that it definitely contributed to it. I shared it from an initial post along with 23 others, who also received 100% negative responses to it. I also added that there were independent posts by others that received identical posts. I sent them a document with the original post/photo that I shared and a large sampling of the comments. I also shared with them my concerns and recommendations. My notes follow:  Billboard not a mural. Call it what it is. Didn‚Äôt we ban billboards in Flagstaff?  Branding? Did Flagstaff logo change from what is on website and other collateral? What happened to Flagstaff ‚ÄúStamp?‚Äù  Look and feel are not in harmony with the surroundings ‚Äì architecture, existing public art.   Preaching to the choir.  Message should be to welcome reinforce activities and the culture of our communities during each of the seasons. It actually could have and still can be something cool! Thank visitors for being here.  Should have included input from arts community. At least BPAC. You can still brand a strong message with art.  What exactly is the purpose? Become like Vegas? Phoenix? LA?  Distracts from our Historic Downtown.  Poster in the middle of the street.  Does it really reflect the culture and vibe of Flagstaff?   Look at those photos on the website. The people. The interactions, the vibrancy. The activity. That is Flagstaff.  Become more innovative and don‚Äôt do what other‚Äôs are doing. Take it further. Use the resources we have in our community. Take it from the ordinary and cheesy to the extraordinary. Put art in the place of advertising. Include that art in the promotions. People will see the coolness of it. The difference.   No one wants to see a billboard in the middle of an intersection. They will look at cool art and if it has our tag line and logo in it, event better.  We are all stakeholders in this not just the City and the Businesses.  The CVB leadership shared with me the purpose of the street mural was to promote Flagstaff as the Destination for All Seasons  and for tourists to share the image from the balcony of the Weatherford on social media. Great idea! I get it.  They went through all the correct channels to get it approved, the City, DBA and got the approval from Sam and Henry at the Weatherford.  The CVB has been looking for effective ways to promote tourism within Flagstaff. They've been doing a great job doing this in other cities and countries with traditional and creative/innovative programs. They're trying something new.  All of this is valid and justified. Only they left out their largest stakeholders - Flagstaff citizens.  There is a lot of change going on in Flagstaff. Yes, we need to promote tourism, ugly as it may seem to many of us. But tourism is Flagstaff's number 1 industry and many of our small and independent businesses rely on it. And our arts, recreation, parks, sciences, and economic development rely on the BBB tax monies generated from it.  So, what was the outcome of the this morning's meeting?  1. They listened intently to the feedback and will use it for future projects  2.  I have been invited to help organize community focus groups for input on future in-city tourism projects such as street murals.  3.  Inclusion of BPAC on future public tourism projects such as this  4.  An invitation to appear on my radio talk show to explain to the community in-city promotion of tourism. Nick Irvine Ryan Sandlin James James Hasapis

description: Kenneth R McIntosh Dear Facebook Friends,   I know that some of you are struggling this morning; with circumstances in your immediate circles, and with tragedy in Las Vegas and other parts of the world. I want to offer a few thoughts, which I hope are helpful:  ‚Ä¢ Mr. Rogers told children in troubled times ‚Äúlook for the helpers,‚Äù and that is good advice for adults as well. Look for the helpers in your family, neighborhood, school, and business. I'll bet they are there.  ‚Ä¢ Take time to breathe. No matter how stressful your circumstances today, you can find a few minutes alone to sit, be still, find a tiny oasis of calm.  ‚Ä¢  Ask God--however you conceive of the Divine-- to fill you with Spirit, to enable you to do what‚Äôs needed for the moment, to give you that extra dose of compassion and capacity that you don‚Äôt feel you have within your natural ability.  ‚Ä¢ Decide that when you have the strength and can make the time (which may not be today‚Äîbut will be sometime in the foreseeable future) you are going to find something that you can do to make the world better. We won‚Äôt all do the same things‚Äîwe may not even perceive the same solution to common problems‚Äîbut we can each do something.  May Divine compassion uphold you, and make you a blessing to others.  -- Ken

description: Mar√≠o Coss Thoughts and prayers without vision and action are about as useful as a fork and knife without food or a table.  When everyday citizens send out their thoughts and prayers that's a symbol of their compassion and them saying "I care about the victims and I'm deeply saddened to hear the news."  When a leader or politician issues their thoughts and prayers, it's a scam. It's like a plumber giving you their thoughts and prayers regarding your clogged toilet. Or someone finding an elderly person in a state of confusion and simply saying "I pray you get home safe."  No. You ask them their name, see if they have an ID tag, or a wallet or purse with their address, you call for help, you DO SOMETHING.  We shouldn't ever accept "thoughts and prayers" from people who are in a position of power and have the ability to actually enact legislation, put laws into effect, etc.  I'm sure the tobacco industry was more than happy to issue "thoughts and prayers" to all the lung cancer victims. It was only after we made laws against advertising tobacco, raised the age limit to purchase tobacco, raised taxes on cigarettes, and issued surgeon general's warnings that we saw lung cancer rates actually decrease.  Thoughts and prayers are a substitute for ACTION. And a poor substitute.  Nobody doubts that we all care about the victims. Seriously. Who the hell hears about a mass shooting and thinks "oh, thank goodness."  Of COURSE WE SEND OUR THOUGHTS AND PRAYERS.  Most of us can't actually do anything to prevent these atrocities from happening. But our leaders can. And when all they have is thoughts and prayers, well, it's not enough. And we should not accept thoughts and prayers anymore. Not only because they don't work to prevent any future events, but they take the place of real action.

For non-evacuees, they will also sell newly donated items for $25 a piece and donate the money to those in need.  ‚Ä¢ Yoga Hell: Free yoga classes, plus an easy drop-off donation site for locals  PETS / ANIMAL BOARDING:  ‚Ä¢ Dickson Ranch in Woodacre is taking horses: ATTN FIRE EVACUEES!
